(3) AI Integration is the New Moat

Tim O’Reilly "AI Integration Is the New Moat",O’REILLY, Oct 2025 https://www.oreilly.com/radar/integration-is-the-new-moat/



Are APIs AI-Ready? Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(4) Most APIs were Designed for Humans!

  • APIs are intended for developers, but not to be interpreted, reasoned about, or safely executed by AI systems


Are APIs AI-Ready? Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(5) Humans Tolerate, Machines Cannot

Human Interpretation:

  • Vague descriptions
  • Inconsistent naming
  • Wrong servers
  • Missing authentication info
  • Missing examples


Are APIs AI-Ready? Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(6) Humans Tolerate, Machines Cannot

Machine Interpretation:



Are APIs AI-Ready? Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(7) Findings from 1500+ Public APIs

  • Broken specs:
    • Invalid or unparsable OpenAPI Docs
    • Missing path parameters / broken `$ref` chains
    • Invalid examples
  • Poor consumer experience:
    • Examples missing
    • Inconsistent naming, unclear HTTP verb usage
    • Vague or generic descriptions
  • Security runtime challenges:
    • No servers or wrong envs
    • Auth info missing (outside OpenAPI)
    • Stale / outdated OpenAPI Documents


Are APIs AI-Ready? Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(8) Typical Ambiguity Example

Agent Interpretation:

  • It might create an offer
  • It mightreplace an user
  • It mightpartially update a offer
  • It mightpatch only some offer fields


Making APIs AI-Ready

Making APIs AI-Ready Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(10) Where to start?



Making APIs AI-Ready Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(11) Readable Summaries and Descriptions

Improves:

  • AI Discoverability, Semantic Clarity, Agent Usability

Where...

  • Objects allowing `summary`: Info, Path Item, Operation, Response, Example, Tag, Reference, ...
  • Objects allowing `description`: Info, Server, Server Variable, Operation, Path Item, External Documentation, Parameter, Request Body, Response, Example, Link, Header, Tag, Reference, Security Scheme, All JSON Schemas, ...


Making APIs AI-Ready Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(12) Semantically Rich Schemas

Improves:

  • AI-Readiness, Agent Usability, Security & Validation

Where...

  • Core JSON Schema fields: type, format, enum, const, required, items, properties, additionalProperties, oneOf, anyOf, allOf, not
  • Constraint fields: minimum, maximum, exclusiveMinimum, exclusiveMaximum, minLength, maxLength, pattern, minItems, maxItems, uniqueItems, minProperties, maxProperties
  • OpenAPI locations: components.schemas, inline parameter schemas, request body schemas, response bodies, header schemas, and any reusable schema fragments.


Making APIs AI-Ready Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(13) Correct HTTP Methods

Improves:

  • Agent Usability, Safety, Idempotency Guarantees

Where...

  • Operation verbs: map semantics to methods correctly: GET = retrieve/list, POST = create/trigger, PUT = full replace, PATCH = partial update, DELETE = remove/revoke.
  • Anti-patterns to avoid: state-changing GET, "action verbs" in paths that conflict with methods (for example POST /users/{id}/update).
  • OpenAPI locations: each HTTP method under paths.<path>.<method>, plus consistent naming in operationId, summary and path templates.


Making APIs AI-Ready Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(14) Full Use of "Examples"

Improves:

  • Developer Experience, AI-Readiness, Agent Planning

Where...

  • Single example fields: example on Parameter, Header, Media Type, Request Body, Response, and JSON Schema objects.
  • Multiple examples: examples on Parameter, Header, Media Type, and Link to illustrate variations, error cases, and edge conditions.
  • OpenAPI locations: paths.<path>.<method>.parameters[].example(s), requestBody.content[*].example(s), responses[status].content[*].example(s), components.schemas.*.example.


Making APIs AI-Ready Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(15) Use RFC 9457 Problem Details for Errors

Improves:

  • Error Consistency, Security Signalling, AI Error Reasoning

Where...

  • Standard error schema: define a reusable ProblemDetails in components.schemas following RFC 9457 (for example type, title, status, detail, instance, plus extension members).
  • Error responses: reference the shared schema from responses[4xx/5xx].content['application/problem+json'].schema and optionally the default response.
  • AI benefit: predictable error shapes make it easier for agents to detect, classify, and recover from failures programmatically.


Making APIs AI-Ready Frank Kilcommins: Getting your APIs AI-Ready

(16) Appropriate HTTP Status Code Usage

Improves:

  • Foundational Compliance, Agent Usability, Observability

Where...

  • Success responses: use correct 2xx codes: 200 for successful retrieval, 201 for created resources, 202 for accepted/async, 204 for no-content updates or deletes.
  • Error responses: model common 4xx/5xx codes with schemas: 400, 401, 403, 404, 409, 422, 500, ... not just a single generic 200 or 500.
  • OpenAPI locations: paths.<path>.<method>.responses[status] with appropriate content, schema and examples per status code.

(19) Our API AI-Readiness Framework

Evaluates APIs across six developer & AI-readiness dimensions

  • Foundational Compliance
  • Developer Experience (including tooling compatibility)
  • Agent Experience
  • Agent Usability
  • Security
  • AI Discoverability
